arts.ttl: Hearts data analysis of Neil Critchley makes for grim reading and his number is up on noxious Tynecastle tenure
arts.sum: Record Sport's Michael Gannon felt Critchley was an ill fit from the start and wonders what analytics has him as top choice

arts.ttl: 'We need the rub of the green': Reading boss on Lincoln defeat and penalty decision
arts.sum: Reading boss Noel Hunt was left baffled by the officials at the LNER Stadium as Lincoln City beat Reading 2-0. Deservedly winning, the Imps netted in both halves and twice hit the woodwork. However, the Royals spent almost an hour with 10 men after Louie Holzman's red card and Sam Smith was denied a 'stonewall' penalty. Speaking after his second successive defeat in charge, Hunt said: " It was [a tough day]. I don’t think we started particularly well in terms of getting to the pace of the game quickly enough. We found ourselves a goal down but off the back of that we grew into it a little bit and started to get a foothold in the game. We were in their final third a bit more but big decision, like the handball when Sam was turning it around the corner, stops him going through on goal.

arts.ttl: 10-man Reading resoundingly beaten at Lincoln as Hunt search for first win continues
arts.sum: 10-man Reading were soundly beaten 2-0 by Lincoln City at the LNER Stadium as Noel Hunt's search for a first win continues. Failing to muster a shot on target all afternoon, goals from Bailey Cadamarteri and Reeco Hackett either side of half-time inflicted a third straight defeat in all competitions for the Royals. Not helped by Louie Holzman's red card in the first half, former Reading youngster Ben House hit the woodwork twice in a resounding win for the play-off chasing Imps. Lincoln took control almost instantaneously from kick-off and Reading did little over the next 45 minutes to wrestle it back. Within three minutes, Joel Pereira was forced to tip Sean Roughan’s drive over the bar and the Royals looked less than convincing in their attempts to clear the ball. To the surprise of nobody in Sincil Bank, the Imps took the lead on eight minutes as Michael Craig was unable to prevent the cross and although Pereira saved from the initial header, Cadamarteri was on hand to fire into the net from close range.

arts.ttl: Lincoln get back to winning ways against 10-man Reading
Reading team news: Two enforced changes for trip to Lincoln City
arts.sum: Reading boss Noel Hunt has made two changes for this afternoon's trip to Lincoln City, with Amadou Mbengue and Ben Elliott missing with injury. Looking for a first win under the legendary former player, the Royals travel to the LNER Stadium sat sixth, but could drop out the play-offs with a defeat and results against them. Mbengue misses out with concussion, while Elliott is to miss a considerable spell with a thigh injury. Joel Pereira remains between the sticks, with a back four of Michael Craig; Tyler Bindon; Louie Holzman and Andre Garcia making up the back four. Lewis Wing and Charlie Savage remain in midfield, with Harvey Knibbs moving in-field for Elliott.

arts.ttl: Live updates: Reading travel to Lincoln City for final match before Christmas
arts.sum: Reading travel to Lincoln City for a lunchtime kick-off in what is the final match before Christmas. Looking to remain in the hunt for the top six, the Royals are still winless under Noel Hunt.

arts.ttl: 'It'll be a good battle' Reading boss assesses Lincoln City ahead of Sincil Bank trip
arts.sum: Reading boss Noel Hunt is expecting 'a good battle' on Saturday as he prepares to take his team to Lincoln City. Michael Skubala's Imps sit ninth in League One, three points behind the Royals, and are looking to take the extra step into the play-offs this campaign after narrowly missing out on the final day last year. Last season, Reading were unbeaten against Lincoln, drawing both fixtures 1-1, but finished 21 points worse off than Saturday's hosts. On Saturday, Lincoln surrendered a two-goal lead to only draw 2-2 at Huddersfield Town, a seventh game without a win for the 2017 FA Cup quarter-finalists.

arts.ttl: 'You can never say never': Reading boss on January window and Hull City 'clause'
arts.sum: 'You can never say never.' Those were the words of Reading manager Noel Hunt as fears over January remain amongst those inside and outside the club as the transfer window looms large. Last winter, key stars such as Nelson Abbey, Tom McIntyre and Tom Holmes were sold without the consent on boss Ruben Selles, a contributing factor to such fan unrest that a match with Port Vale was abandoned due to a pitch invasion from supporters. Hunt is the new man in the hotseat, following Selles' exit to Hull City earlier in the month, but 12 months on it is still impossible to rule out such behaviour as the club remain locked in a loveless relationship with owner Dai Yongge. Reading play three matches before January, with key stars such as Harvey Knibbs, Lewis Wing and Tyler Bindon already being linked away.

arts.ttl: Reading 'in talks' over possibility of extending loan for Wolves star
arts.sum: Reading manager Noel Hunt has confirmed that the club are in talks with Wolverhampton Wanderers loanee Chem Campbell over the possibility of extending his loan deal. The 21-year-old, who has made eight appearances for the Old Gold to date, has nine goal contributions to his name so far this season but is only under contract until January 5. The EFL only cleared his arrival on deadline day due to the expectation that Rob Couhig was to takeover, something which did not happen and is now leading to the 75-year-old filing a lawsuit against the club. A regular since arriving, Campbell has improved throughout the campaign and is regularly one of the top performers for the Royals. Speaking ahead of Saturday's trip to Lincoln City, Hunt explained that discussions are being had over any possible options.

arts.ttl: 'Months rather than days': Reading hit with injury blow ahead of Lincoln City trip
arts.sum: Reading have been hit with a double injury blow ahead of Saturday's trip to Lincoln City, with Ben Elliott and Amadou Mbengue out. The Royals travel up to Sincil Bank looking for a first win under Noel Hunt to kickstart a busy festive period. Mbengue was taken off at half-time of Saturday's 3-0 defeat to Blackpool with a mild concussion, while midfielder Elliott limped off in the closing stages and is now seeing a specialist for a thigh injury. Speaking to the media ahead of the trip to face the Imps, manager Hunt said: "Amadou [Mbengue] had a mild concussion so he will miss the weekend. [Ben] Elliott sustained a decent thigh injury. We’re waiting to see the extent of it- he sees a specialist tomorrow. Probably months rather than days.
